channel.title: Scraping on Khaleel Musleh
channel.description: Recent content in Scraping on Khaleel Musleh

item.title: Scraping Google Calendar events
item.author: maxhalford25@gmail.com (Khaleel Musleh)
item.description: At my day job we deal with enterprise customers. They pay us a subscription fee, and in return we help them in various ways to reduce their carbon footprint. To keep the boat afloat, we need to make some money. We shouldn’t spend more money than we make. So we need to keep track of our revenue and costs. Our gross margin is (revenue - cost) / revenue, where the cost is mostly the salaries of our employees.

item.title: Do LLMs identify fonts?
item.author: maxhalford25@gmail.com (Khaleel Musleh)
item.description:
Spoiler: not really

dafont.com is a wonderful website that contains a large collection of fonts. It’s more comprehensive and esoteric than Google Fonts. One of its features is a forum where users can ask for help identifying fonts – check out this poor fellow who’s been waiting for over two years and bumped his thread. I thought it would be interesting to see if an LLM could do this task, so I scraped the forum and set up a benchmark.

item.title: Web scraping, upside down
item.author: maxhalford25@gmail.com (Khaleel Musleh)
item.description:
Motivation

Web scraping is the art of extracting information from web pages. A web page is essentially an amalgamation of HTML tags. Usually, we’re looking for a particular piece of information on a given web page. This may be done by fetching the HTML content of the page in question, and then running some HTML parsing logic. It’s quite straightforward.

There are many tools in the wild to perform web scraping. For instance, in Python, you may use requests in combination with Beautiful Soup. You can also automate some of the more mundane aspects of scraping by using Scrapy.
